item.title: Kapow! – a punchy PowerShell framework
item.description:
Earlier today I released a new project called Kapow!. After growing more and more frustrated over how slow Cygwin was1 and not being able to use Oh my Zsh! on my Windows machine I decided to hack together something that atleast resembled some kind of framework. Right now it has quite a few aliases, scripts, tab completion and themes. I haven’t really used the PowerShell that much so the code looks a bit wonky but hey, it works! My initial thoughts about writing scripts for the the PowerShell are not bad… I think that I actually like it, which is a shock. This is how my prompt looks right now2:

It’s defintively an improvement over the standard look and behaviour. I haven’t noticed any slowness at all either, but the plugin library isn’t that huge right now. I’m hoping to expanded it a bit more and I’ll be happy if anyone wants to contribute!

  1. It takes about 10 seconds to launch it. No joke.↩

  2. I’m also using Console2.↩

item.title: My Linux setup
item.description:
I’ve mentioned before how I love to read about other people’s setups so I decided to throw together a quite detailed but comprehensive document of what I currently use for my Linux setup and how to actually set it up1. So far I’m happy with what I’m using but I plan to keep it up to date if I decide to add or change something.

  1. Those notes are mainly written for me, but I figured that it might be useful for someone else too.↩

item.title: It's the little things (again)
item.description:
Today’s smile is brought to me by this:

I must sound like a total ass1 but the truth is that I just get so happy when someone finds the stuff I make actually useful!

  1. I’m a swede, so I’m naturally affected by the Law of Jante.↩

item.title: The new Jekyll Rake Boilerplate
item.description:
I finally sat down and the refactor most of the code in my most popular project but don’t worry, it’s still quite a mess1.

  1. I haven’t written any Ruby code for quite some time.↩

item.title: hpr1197 :: What I do with bash scripts
item.description: I recently revisited this episode from Hacker Public Radio that Jonathan Kulp did and it may very well be one of the coolest episodes I’ve ever heard.
